thread.title_full: Balint Alovits from Budapest captures spiral staircases | Daily Mail Online

author: Unity Blott For Mailonline
title: Balint Alovits from Budapest captures spiral staircases
text:
A Hungarian photographer has created these dizzying images of spiral staircases.
Balint Alovits , from Budapest, set about capturing the 'unnoticed architectural masterpieces' around his hometown by standing at the same central point - either directly at the top or directly at the bottom - of each stairwell.
The artist, who is fascinated by interiors, says the captivating images represent 'an infinite vortex that feels out of this world'. So can you tell which way is up?
Balint Alovits' latest collection of photographs, taken in his hometown of Budapest, Hungary, focuses on the beauty of Bauhaus and Art Deco spiral staircases around the city
In some images, like this minimalist Bauhaus structure, it is almost impossible to tell which way you are looking. Alovits says the images 'create a new dimension by splitting space and time'
Alovits stood at the exact same central point at the top or bottom of each staircase to capture the images. Together, the resulting pictures make up his Time Machine collection
This tiled Art Deco staircase creates a dizzying effect with the ground appearing to shrink before the viewer's eyes. The pictures are described as a 'photographic exploration' of Bauhaus and Art Deco caracoles (spiral stairways) in his hometown
The surreal 'vortex' style images evoke a sense of vertigo when looking from the top down. Alovits said he wanted to capture 'the pulling energy of these spiral forms'
This striking triangular structure could almost be taken from a sketch by M. C. Escher. The photographer says the architectural details 'evoke the idea of infinity'
The striking images evoke a feeling of vertigo but commenting on this photograph one social media Quote: : 'I wonder how many people have tried to slide down the banister?'
An ornate staircase in Budapest is the subject of this image from Alovits' latest collection, Time Machine. The photographer was born in the Hungarian capital in 1987
One image, depicting a white structure with black railings, resembles the inside of a shell. The 'beautiful' images have left some social media users in a state of confusion
Alovits stood directly in the centre of a staircase to capture this image looking up towards the ceiling from the ground floor. The artist also works as a commercial and interior photographer
Which way is up? Alovits' striking images focus on Bauhaus and Art Deco caracoles (spiral stairways) in his hometown of Budapest, Hungary
Up or down? This confusing image is in keeping with Alovits' fascination with spatiality. Another recent collection from the artist focuses on a man-made beach on Copenhagen
The photographer, who he loves discovering unknown places, says on his website he is constantly looking for 'the pure aesthetics and harmony in nature and built environments'
Some of Alovits' images, taken from the ground floor looking up, have prompted social media users to joke they looked like 'a warp hole to another dimension'
